column2: CHAPTER XXXI.
column3: CHAPTER thirty one.

column2: HOW MARY PASSED THE NIGHT.
column3: HOW MARY PASSED THE NIGHT.

column2: To think That all this long interminable night, Which I have passed in thinking on two words-- 'Guilty'--'Not Guilty!'--like one happy moment O'er many a head hath flown unheeded by; O'er happy sleepers dreaming in their bliss Of bright to-morrows--or far happier still, With deep breath buried in forgetfulness. O all the dismallest images of death Did swim before my eyes!
column3: To think That all this long interminable night, Which I have passed in thinking on two words- 'Guilty'--'Not Guilty!'--like one happy moment O'er many a head hath flown unheeded by; O'er happy sleepers dreaming in their bliss Of bright to morrows-or far happier still, With deep breath buried in forgetfulness. O all the dismallest images of death Did swim before my eyes!

column2: WILSON.
column3: WILSON.

column2: And now, where was Mary?
column3: And now, where was Mary?

column2: How Job's heart would have been relieved of one of its cares if he could have seen her: for he was in a miserable state of anxiety about her; and many and many a time through that long night he scolded her and himself; her for her obstinacy, and himself for his weakness in yielding to her obstinacy, when she insisted on being the one to follow and find out Will.
column3: How Job's heart would have been relieved of one of its cares if he could have seen her: for he was in a miserable state of anxiety about her; and many and many a time through that long night he scolded her and himself; her for her obstinacy, and himself for his weakness in yielding to her obstinacy, when she insisted on being the one to follow and find out Will.

column2: She did not pass that night in bed any more than Job; but she was under a respectable roof, and among kind, though rough people.
column3: She did not pass that night in bed any more than Job; but she was under a respectable roof, and among kind, though rough people.

column2: She had offered no resistance to the old boatman, when he had clutched her arm, in order to insure her following him, as he threaded the crowded dock-ways, and dived up strange bye-streets.
column3: She had offered no resistance to the old boatman, when he had clutched her arm, in order to insure her following him, as he threaded the crowded dock ways, and dived up strange bye streets.

column2: She came on meekly after him, scarcely thinking in her stupor where she was going, and glad (in a dead, heavy way) that some one was deciding things for her.
column3: She came on meekly after him, scarcely thinking in her stupor where she was going, and glad (in a dead, heavy way) that some one was deciding things for her.

column2: He led her to an old-fashioned house, almost as small as house could be, which had been built long ago, before all the other part of the street, and had a country-town look about it in the middle of that bustling back street.
column3: He led her to an old-fashioned house, almost as small as house could be, which had been built long ago, before all the other part of the street, and had a country town look about it in the middle of that bustling back street.

column2: There! giving a great slap of one hand on her back.
column3: There! giving a great slap of one hand on her back.

column2: The room was light and bright, and roused Mary (perhaps the slap on her back might help a little, too), and she felt the awkwardness of accounting for her presence to a little bustling old woman who had been moving about the fire-place on her entrance.
column3: The room was light and bright, and roused Mary (perhaps the slap on her back might help a little, too), and she felt the awkwardness of accounting for her presence to a little bustling old woman who had been moving about the fire place on her entrance.

column2: The boatman took it very quietly, never deigning to give any explanation, but sitting down in his own particular chair, and chewing tobacco, while he looked at Mary with the most satisfied air imaginable, half triumphantly, as if she were the captive of his bow and spear, and half defyingly, as if daring her to escape.
column3: The boatman took it very quietly, never deigning to give any explanation, but sitting down in his own particular chair, and chewing tobacco, while he looked at Mary with the most satisfied air imaginable, half triumphantly, as if she were the captive of his bow and spear, and half defyingly, as if daring her to escape.

column2: The old woman, his wife, stood still, poker in hand, waiting to be told who it was that her husband had brought home so unceremoniously; but, as she looked in amazement the girl's cheek flushed, and then blanched to a dead whiteness; a film came over her eyes, and catching at the dresser for support in that hot whirling room, she fell in a heap on the floor.
column3: The old woman, his wife, stood still, poker in hand, waiting to be told who it was that her husband had brought home so unceremoniously; but, as she looked in amazement the girl's cheek flushed, and then blanched to a dead whiteness; a film came over her eyes, and catching at the dresser for support in that hot whirling room, she fell in a heap on the floor.

column2: Both man and wife came quickly to her assistance.
column3: Both man and wife came quickly to her assistance.

column2: They raised her up, still insensible, and he supported her on one knee, while his wife pattered away for some cold fresh water.
column3: They raised her up, still insensible, and he supported her on one knee, while his wife pattered away for some cold fresh water.

column2: She threw it straight over Mary; but though it caused a great sob, the eyes still remained closed, and the face as pale as ashes.
column3: She threw it straight over Mary; but though it caused a great sob, the eyes still remained closed, and the face as pale as ashes.

column2: Who is she, Ben? asked the woman, as she rubbed her unresisting, powerless hands.
column3: Who is she, Ben? asked the woman, as she rubbed her unresisting, powerless hands.

column2: How should I know? answered her husband gruffly.
column3: How should I know? answered her husband gruffly.

column2: Well-a-well! (in a soothing tone, such as you use to irritated children), and as if half to herself, "I only thought you might, you know, as you brought her home.

column2: Poor thing! we must not ask aught about her, but that she needs help.
column3: Poor thing! we must not ask aught about her, but that she needs help.

column2: I wish I'd my salts at home, but I lent 'em to Mrs. Burton, last Sunday in church, for she could not keep awake through the sermon.
column3: I wish I'd my salts at home, but I lent 'em to mrs Burton, last Sunday in church, for she could not keep awake through the sermon.

column2: Dear-a-me, how white she is!"
column3: Dear a me, how white she is!"

column2: Here! you hold her up a bit, said her husband.
column3: Here! you hold her up a bit, said her husband.

column2: She did as he desired, still crooning to herself, not caring for his short, sharp interruptions as she went on; and, indeed, to her old, loving heart, his crossest words fell like pearls and diamonds, for he had been the husband of her youth; and even he, rough and crabbed as he was, was secretly soothed by the sound of her voice, although not for worlds, if he could have helped it, would he have shown any of the love that was hidden beneath his rough outside.
column3: She did as he desired, still crooning to herself, not caring for his short, sharp interruptions as she went on; and, indeed, to her old, loving heart, his crossest words fell like pearls and diamonds, for he had been the husband of her youth; and even he, rough and crabbed as he was, was secretly soothed by the sound of her voice, although not for worlds, if he could have helped it, would he have shown any of the love that was hidden beneath his rough outside.

column2: What's the old fellow after? said she, bending over Mary, so as to accommodate the drooping head.

column2: Ay, I see now, he's his wits about him; burnt feathers is always good for a faint. But they don't bring her round, poor wench!

column2: Now what's he after next?

column2: Well! he is a bright one, my old man!
column3: Well! he is a bright one, my old man!

column2: That I never thought of that, to be sure!" exclaimed she, as he produced a square bottle of smuggled spirits, labelled "Golden Wasser," from a corner cupboard in their little room.

column2: That'll do! said she, as the dose he poured into Mary's open mouth made her start and cough.
column3: That'll do! said she, as the dose he poured into Mary's open mouth made her start and cough.

column2: Bless the man!	Bless the man!

column2: It's just like him to be so tender and thoughtful!"
column3: It's just like him to be so tender and thoughtful!"

column2: Not a bit! snarled he, as he was relieved by Mary's returning colour, and opened eyes, and wondering, sensible gaze; "not a bit! I never was such a fool afore."
column3: Not a bit! snarled he, as he was relieved by Mary's returning colour, and opened eyes, and wondering, sensible gaze; "not a bit! I never was such a fool afore."

column2: His wife helped Mary to rise, and placed her in a chair.
column3: His wife helped Mary to rise, and placed her in a chair.

column2: All's right now, young woman? asked the boatman, anxiously.
column3: All's right now, young woman? asked the boatman, anxiously.

column2: I'm sure, sir, I don't know rightly how to thank you," faltered Mary, softly forth.
column3: I'm sure, sir, I don't know rightly how to thank you," faltered Mary, softly forth.

column2: Be hanged to you and your thanks. And he shook himself, took his pipe, and went out without deigning another word; leaving his wife sorely puzzled as to the character and history of the stranger within her doors.
column3: Be hanged to you and your thanks. And he shook himself, took his pipe, and went out without deigning another word; leaving his wife sorely puzzled as to the character and history of the stranger within her doors.

column2: Mary watched the boatman leave the house, and then, turning her sorrowful eyes to the face of her hostess, she attempted feebly to rise, with the intention of going away,--where she knew not.
column3: Mary watched the boatman leave the house, and then, turning her sorrowful eyes to the face of her hostess, she attempted feebly to rise, with the intention of going away,--where she knew not.

column2: Nay! nay! who e'er thou be'st, thou'rt not fit to go out into the street.	Nay! nay! who e'er thou be'st, thou'rt not fit to go out into the street.

column2: Perhaps" (sinking her voice a little) "thou'rt a bad one; I almost misdoubt thee, thou'rt so pretty.

column2: Well-a-well!
column3: Well a well!

column2: it's the bad ones as have the broken hearts, sure enough; good folk never get utterly cast down, they've always getten hope in the Lord: it's the sinful as bear the bitter, bitter grief in their crushed hearts, poor souls; it's them we ought, most of all, to pity and to help.
column3: it's the bad ones as have the broken hearts, sure enough; good folk never get utterly cast down, they've always getten hope in the Lord: it's the sinful as bear the bitter, bitter grief in their crushed hearts, poor souls; it's them we ought, most of all, to pity and to help.

column2: She shanna leave the house to-night, choose who she is,--worst woman in Liverpool, she shanna.

column2: I wished I knew where th' old man picked her up, that I do."

column2: Still talking half to herself and half to Mary, the old woman prepared tea, and urged her visitor to eat and refresh herself.
column3: Still talking half to herself and half to Mary, the old woman prepared tea, and urged her visitor to eat and refresh herself.

column2: But Mary shook her head at the proffered food, and only drank a cup of tea with thirsty eagerness.
column3: But Mary shook her head at the proffered food, and only drank a cup of tea with thirsty eagerness.

column2: For the spirits had thrown her into a burning heat, and rendered each impression received through her senses of the most painful distinctness and intensity, while her head ached in a terrible manner.
column3: For the spirits had thrown her into a burning heat, and rendered each impression received through her senses of the most painful distinctness and intensity, while her head ached in a terrible manner.

column2: She disliked speaking, her power over her words seemed so utterly gone.
column3: She disliked speaking, her power over her words seemed so utterly gone.

column2: She used quite different expressions to those she intended.

column2: So she kept silent, while Mrs. Sturgis (for that was the name of her hostess) talked away, and put her tea-things by, and moved about incessantly, in a manner that increased the dizziness in Mary's head. She felt as if she ought to take leave for the night and go.
column3: So she kept silent, while mrs Sturgis (for that was the name of her hostess) talked away, and put her tea things by, and moved about incessantly, in a manner that increased the dizziness in Mary's head. She felt as if she ought to take leave for the night and go.

column3: Presently the old man came back, crosser and gruffer than when he went away.

column2: I'd bet a penny it has changed sin' thou looked."

column2: She looked out of their little window at a weather-cock, near, glittering in the moonlight; and as she was a sailor's wife, she instantly recognised the unfavourable point at which the indicator seemed stationary, and giving a heavy sigh, turned into the room, and began to beat about in her own mind for some other mode of comfort.
column3: She looked out of their little window at a weather cock, near, glittering in the moonlight; and as she was a sailor's wife, she instantly recognised the unfavourable point at which the indicator seemed stationary, and giving a heavy sigh, turned into the room, and began to beat about in her own mind for some other mode of comfort.

column2: There's no one else who can prove what you want at the trial to-morrow, is there? asked she.
column3: There's no one else who can prove what you want at the trial to morrow, is there? asked she.

column2: Mary went up-stairs murmuring thanks and blessings on those who took the stranger in.

column2: Mrs. Sturgis led her into a little room redolent of the sea and foreign lands.
column3: mrs Sturgis led her into a little room redolent of the sea and foreign lands.

column2: There was a small bed for one son, bound for China; and a hammock slung above for another, who was now tossing in the Baltic.
column3: There was a small bed for one son, bound for China; and a hammock slung above for another, who was now tossing in the Baltic.

column2: The sheets looked made out of sail-cloth, but were fresh and clean in spite of their brownness.
column3: The sheets looked made out of sail cloth, but were fresh and clean in spite of their brownness.
